title: 111_hr6514
content: The "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010" prohibits the use of certain stimulus and disaster relief funds for business relocation incentives. The "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010" prohibits using specified funds for business relocation incentives, preventing businesses from moving operations between states or reducing operations in one state while expanding in another. The "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010" prohibits the use of certain funds for business relocation incentives. Public Law 111-226, the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010, and the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act are referenced for disaster relief funds. Enforcement includes a political subdivision petitioning the Governor for violations. The "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010" prohibits the use of funds for business relocation incentives. Governors can request investigations by the Secretary of Commerce for violations of the act. The "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010" prohibits the use of funds for business relocation incentives. If a violation of the act occurs, the State responsible must repay the funds used in violation to the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury will then take action to collect on the claim. The "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010" prohibits states from receiving certain funds until repayment is made for any violations. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report biannually for five years after the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to specific committees on the impact of the provisions in the "Protecting Jobs in Your State Act of 2010." The report must include details on petitions received by the Secretary of Commerce, claims of the United States, and funds withheld. The term "State" in this section includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the US Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. This section applies to funds obligated by a State or its political subdivision after the enactment of this Act.
